@jzgithub1 The above design will only work if we upgrade to the latest ZK 3.5. There may be other implications of that, so that should be done first, as its own task, before implementing the above.

An alternative might be to simply use fewer watchers in the first place, by changing the design for table config updates to use a single global watcher on a single field, named something like "/configChanged" which is updated on every config update, and guards every config read. This strategy would reduce the number of watchers as a whole, and would also work on the current version of ZK we use.
Thanks @ctubbsii .  Glad I didn't go down that road too far.

To be clear, I don't know for sure, which methods are our best bets in terms of simplifying the code or reducing the number of watchers. It may require some investigation, and prototyping of the various options. I just wanted to make sure whoever worked on this was aware that there are other possible solutions.

The new Bulk Import for 2.0 is more granular.  If you use something like map reduce to inspect the files to create the load plan before performing the bulk import, then that should greatly reduce time spent holding a table lock.  You can also bulk import to a table offline.

premise: full table locks would not be an issue as long as they are very short (sub-second).
Hence if we were to solve https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ACCUMULO-3235, then merging would not require long locks.  Basically if we keep track of the valid range within an rfile for every entry in the metadata, then we can avoid having to pre-chop the files when merging and avoid long table locks.

@ctubbsii the verbose option only applies to safemode which basically only lists the files to delete.  One would not likely want to set all the log.info messages in this class to print to the console.  Would it make sense to have safemode default to both log and console.  The only time this option would be set is to review the output before doing a GC.  I'm inclined to think that safemode is not really a configuration file option.

For the verbose flag, it can go away. The single print statement that the verbose flag currently controls need not be optional. We can always print that message.

For the safeMode flag, we can deprecate that and have it print a warning if used. It can be replaced by `gc.safeMode` configuration property option (or similar). Since configuration options can already be passed on the command-line, it makes sense to replace `--safeMode` with the standard way of passing options on the command-line as `-o gc.safeMode` (I believe that's the format), for consistency. Would need to make sure that boolean options passed this way are implicitly set to true.

Now, in reference to the latter piece - cleaning up ServerOpts and creating a property(ies) for --address (NOTE: maybe I'm overthinking it):
This could be a generic address override like it is now "server.bind.address" or specific to the service like "tserver.bind.address".  I'm not sure how either of these could be represented in the config (accumulo.properties).  The "server.bind.address" is ambiguous and "tserver.bind.address" could be mulitple.  Yes, as overrides they make sense on the command line `-o server.bind.address=blah .`   Since these would really over ever be set on the command line then I think I vote for the generic form.

> Since these would really over ever be set on the command line then I think I vote for the generic form.

I don't think it's the case that they would only be set on the command line, since the most common scenario is to set it to `0.0.0.0`, at least for the bind address. I think it should follow the current conventions of `{tserver,master,gc,monitor}.*`, so they can coexist in the same distributed configuration file. For the advertisement address.. that would probably be more common to set on the command-line, when it differs from the bind address, but even there, I think it's best to follow the current conventions.

Also, I haven't thought this through fully, but these address fields could also deprecate/replace the port option. That might be worth considering, since it'd be very intuitive to specify the bind address as `0.0.0.0:50095` rather than specify the bind address as `0.0.0.0`, and a separate field for the port as `50095`. Keeping the config non-breaking for current users, and the behavior when the port is specified in both locations would be figure out and define.

As follow-on, NativeMap, NMIterator, and ConcurrentIterator in NativeMap.java could all be made AutoCloseable, and the close method replace the delete methods. The NMSKVIter would still need a Cleaner, to clean up its ConcurrentIterator, though, because SortedKeyValueIterators aren't closeable.

Thanks for looking into this, @BukrosSzabolcs . This is an interesting feature.

However, a lot has changed since that issue was last discussed over 6 years ago. I'm not finding a compelling need for it today (but could be convinced). In my view, it is trivial for a user to implement such a thing by simply having their own naming convention for deleted tables, and taking them offline. This change would introduce a lot of extra code, increasing complexity, without a lot of value (not anything a user can't already do today quite easily and entirely from the client side).

Perhaps a more useful feature might be to add "table tags", to assist the user in tagging tables with user-defined tags, like a `deleted` tag or a `date_deleted` tag? Those could be stored very trivially in the ZooKeeper node information for a table, and retrieved with simple APIs, without a lot of code. It could enable complex user requirements like identifying when a table was deleted, but without us having to grow Accumulo complexity much. Generic table tags could also support lots of other user features, like `created_by` or `created_on` or `delete_after` or whatever.

That IT is designed to be a basic smoke test to ensure we can put data into Accumulo and it subsequently view it. It's not designed or well-suited for performance testing or experimentation.

> I re-ran the tests again a few times and the running times went up and down a little from run to run so I really can't say that I have improved anything here.

Variance is pretty normal. If you want to see if this code changed things in a meaningful way, you'll probably need to do some controlled experiments with various sizes and settings to demonstrate (or disprove) improved throughput with the change(s). A good experiment will also eliminate the JVM startup times as a variable by avoiding using MiniAccumuloInstance (used by ReadWriteIT), and would run with several tservers (to ensure the binning part of the batch writer is exercised, since that's a relevant code path for the question of throughput).

> I will look at the TabletServerBatchWriter class a little more deeply to see if I can come up with any better ideas on how to improve throughput. I will comment on issue #1120 in the issue thread instead of the pull request from now on.

The ideas in this PR don't seem to be very similar to the 2-layer queuing strategy described in the old JIRA issue linked on #1120. One difference with this code and what was there before this and #1348 is that Exceptions thrown by the `bw.close()` method no longer get wrapped with an `AccumuloException`. In particular, this `close` method can return `MutationsRejectedException`, which is already an instance of `AccumuloException`. If any code relied on those being wrapped, such code could fail or behave incorrectly, when it tries to unwrap the `AccumuloException` now thrown here. The same is true for RTEs, including `InterruptedException` which is wrapped by a RTE in `TabletServerBatchWriter.close()` called by `BatchWriterImpl.close()`.

If no calling code tries to unwrap these exceptions, and merely propagates them to be logged or to kill the JVM, it probably doesn't matter.
It is my understanding the the try-with-resources will handle any exceptions thrown by the close with the handling in the catch block - which would still wrap the exception as an AccumuloException.
